sect1.title: Requirements
sect1.para: Web:Extend currently requires PHP 5.2. It may work with older versions of PHP but they are not officially supported so we cannot provide any guarantee.
Web:Extend requires the following extensions:
There's a driver available for most databases, including PostgreSQL, MySQL, SQLite, Oracle, MSSQL. PDO is also supported and all the PDO drivers are expected to work.
The following extensions are required by some of the less used features of the framework, but you might not need them:

listitem.para: CURL for the QUnit test suite
fileinfo for file management in the extra library

sect1.para: Finally, the following extensions are highly recommended:

listitem.para: APC for file and data cache
gettext for faster string translation functions

sect1.para: If you intend to generate PDF files, you will be required to add the pdflatex command to your PATH. This command can be found in the texlive package, or in any other LaTeX distribution.

If your application needs to send emails, you'll want to install an MTA at least in the production environment. We recommend postfix as it doesn't require any particular configuration if you only need to send emails.

sect1.title: Preliminary considerations
sect1.para: Before performing any configuration you should probably ask yourself a few questions about your project. These considerations are applicable for both new and existing projects.

listitem.para: What environment am I targetting? Development, test, production?
What web server am I using?
Does the project use a database? Do I have the connection information?
Does the project need any cron jobs installed?

sect1.para: Some of those considerations will be walked through in the following chapters. We'll explain the more general configuration right away though.

sect1.title: Web server configuration
sect1.para: The configuration depends on which web server you are using. Since all the developers are using Apache 2.2, we are going to explain how to configure it. Feel free to submit guidelines to get Web:Extend working with other web servers. See for more information.

First of all it is recommended that you enable mod_rewrite. While not mandatory, mod_rewrite allows you to write clean URLs. No need to reload Apache yet, we still have to configure the site for the application:
sect1.screen: # a2enmod rewrite Enabling module rewrite. Run '/etc/init.d/apache2 restart' to activate new configuration!

note.title: Development environment
note.para: It is good practice to create a local domain name for each of the applications you are working on. A local domain name allows you to test the application just like it would be on the production server.

While they were only tested on Ubuntu, the following guidelines should work for most unix systems. You only have to add a new local host to your /etc/hosts file. Open it with the editor of your choice and add a line below the localhost one for your own local domain name:

Use a different IP than localhost (or other domains you may have) so that Apache can distinguish between the two domains. If you're worried about conflicting domain names on your network, you can use myapp.localhost instead.
Then configure Apache like you would otherwise, using the local domain name newly created.

sect1.para: We recommend that you configure Apache log files per application (or per domain if your site has multiple domains). This allows you to easily check for errors or generate stats for the application.
The following file will configure the application myapp fully, by defining the folders, rewrite rules and log files. Don't forget to change the paths to the actual paths on your environment.
This file should be saved in the sites-available/ Apache subdirectory on Debian-based distributions. Then use the following command to enable the site:
sect1.screen: # a2ensite myapp Enabling site myapp. Run '/etc/init.d/apache2 reload' to activate new configuration!
sect1.para: On other systems you might have to append it to an existing configuration file. In this case no need to call a2ensite.
Now that everything is set, reload Apache:
sect1.screen: # /etc/init.d/apache2 reload * Reloading web server config apache2 [ OK ]
sect1.para: If you made a mistake in the configuration, Apache will warn you and will ignore your request. Correct your errors and try again until you get it working.

note.para: You can also use the .htaccess file available in the share/apache/ folder of your Web:Extend installation. Note that it only defines the rules for URL rewriting, and it can be used when accessing the application as a subfolder of a domain. Still, it is recommended to configure a site in Apache directly.

sect1.title: Database configuration
sect1.para: Almost all projects require some form of database. Depending on your application you'll prefer one over another, but in general we tend to recommend PostgreSQL as it is a solid all-purpose open-source relational database available on all the common platforms.

caution.para: We recommend not using MySQL if you need a relational database. MySQL will allow more or less control over the relationships between tables depending on the backend storage used, often with additional restrictions on other components. You can still use it, of course, but it'll take extra care in designing and writing your application.

sect1.para: To install PostgreSQL on a Debian-based system, please follow the guide. On other systems the installation and configuration should be relatively similar, refer to your vendor's documentation for more information.
First you need to install the PostgreSQL package:
sect1.screen: # apt-get install postgresql Setting up postgresql ...
sect1.para: The latest stable version will be automatically installed. Then you need to create a database and a user to access it. All PostgreSQL administration operations can be performed directly from the postgresql system account. Just log on this account and create what you need:
sect1.screen: # su - postgres $ createdb mydb $ createuser -P myuser Enter password for new role: Enter it again: Shall the new role be a superuser? (y/n) n Shall the new role be allowed to create databases? (y/n) n Shall the new role be allowed to create more new roles? (y/n) n
sect1.para: It is recommended that the user of your application isn't a superuser. Remember, if there's a security vulnerability in your application and the attacker can execute any query he wishes, he would have access to all your databases on this server if you made a superuser. The easiest solution for a start is to grant all privileges on your database, although it's possible to further restrict the privileges depending on your application's needs.
You can grant privileges to users using psql. psql is the PostgreSQL command-line shell, allowing you to write SQL queries directly.
sect1.screen:
$ psql psql (8.4.2) Type "help" for help.
postgres=# GRANT ALL ON DATABASE mydb TO myuser WITH GRANT OPTION; GRANT postgres=# \q $ exit
sect1.para: You should now be able to connect to the database mydb with the user myuser and the password you entered earlier.
